turns.speaker: CHET
turns.text: Hey!!!... Johnnie Farragut. How are you, my man.

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: Real good, Chet... It's been awhile.

turns.speaker: CHET
turns.text: Everythin's relative. Where's that Marietta Pace Fortune? You two didn't split up, I hope.

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: No... She's fine. Back home.

turns.speaker: CHET
turns.text: What'll it be? The regular? Black Label?

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: Set one up.

turns.speaker: CHET
turns.text: So who you out sleuthin' for now?... Can I help ya?

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: Actually, I'm lookin' for Marietta's daughter, Lula. Her and 'er beau took off the other day. Marietta's real upset about it.

turns.speaker: CHET
turns.text: Hell, that rings a bell. Someone told me somebody lookin' like her was at the Nothin' Fancy yesterday.

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: Sounds right... I'll check it out.

turns.speaker: CHET
turns.text: You hitched yet?

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: No sir...

turns.speaker: CHET
turns.text: It's none of my business, but when are you and Marietta gonna tie the knot? I always wondered why you never did.

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: Not for lack of love, I can tell ya that.

turns.speaker: CHET
turns.text: That's what I mean... Always looked like you was just knocked out in love... Was real nice to see.

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: I'll tell ya though, it's comin' up to the time when Marietta and me might just set up house together and settle down... I think that time's comin' up right soon. But like you said, everythin's relative.

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: Alright... By all means. Make yourselves at home.

turns.speaker: DROP SHADOW
turns.text: Muchas gracias.

turns.speaker: DROP SHADOW
turns.text: No big buildings like in New Orleans.

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: Whattaya do there?

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: I thought you two were in Austin, Texas. Or Takes-us, as they say in these parts.

turns.speaker: DROP SHADOW
turns.text: We were. Now Mr. San Pedro Sula and I are on our way back to Utila, in the morning.

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: So, it's back to the islands.

turns.speaker: DROP SHADOW
turns.text: Yes. Mr. San Pedro Sula spoke yesterday to his son, Archibald Leach San Pedro Sula, who is named after Cary Grant, and he told them there was a shooting.

turns.speaker: DROP SHADOW
turns.text: But how are you finding New Orleans, Senor Farragut?

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: Call me Johnnie... N.O. has always been a good town to sit around in.

turns.speaker: DROP SHADOW
turns.text: Mr. San Pedro Sula is from Honduras.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Do you know Honduras, Johnny?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Oh, many things...

turns.speaker: DROP SHADOW
turns.text: Mr. San Pedro Sula's got an appliance shop.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: But I am also with the government.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: That is my permiso.

turns.speaker: DROP SHADOW
turns.text: Mr. San Pedro Sula's permit to kill.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Only if necessary, of course, and only in my own country.

turns.speaker: DROP SHADOW
turns.text: Mr. San Pedro Sula's authorized to carry a .45.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: United States Marine issue, before they made the unfortunate switch to the less dependable nine millimeters. I have it here, in my briefcase.

turns.speaker: DROP SHADOW
turns.text: He wants to take Mr. San Pedro Sula and me bass fishing.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: We are in the same businesses and also we are fishermen.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: My name's George Kovich. Bet you've heard of me.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Don't know that I have... Should I know about you for anythin' in particular?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Was in all the papers three years ago. I'm seventy-six, was only seventy- three then. Had a business in Buffalo, New York, called Rats With Wings. Killed pigeons for anyone who wanted 'em killed.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: If your neighbors didn't mind, how'd you get put out of business?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Woman drivin' down the street spotted me with on a roof with my rifle. She called the police and they came over and arrested me. Thought I was a sniper! Boys at the VFW loved that one. Cops didn't understand about the pigeons, the damage they do to personal property. I used to complain to the city but they never lifted a finger. I was gonna put out poison, but I was afraid somebody's cat would eat it. Hell, I had six cats myself. So I used the .22 because it didn't make much noise and the ammo was cheap.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: What happened on the charges?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Guilty on a reduced charge. Hundred dollar fine and ordered to desist. Pigeons carry diseases and muss up the place. You seen it. Plain filth.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: The Good Witch...

turns.speaker: GOOD WITCH
turns.text: Sailor... Lula loves you.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: But I'm a robber and a manslaughterer and I haven't had any parental guidance.

turns.speaker: GOOD WITCH
turns.text: She's forgiven you of all these things... You love her... Don't be afraid, Sailor.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: But I'm wild at heart.

turns.speaker: GOOD WITCH
turns.text: If you are truly wild at heart, you'll fight for your dreams... Don't turn away from love, Sailor... Don't turn away from love... Don't turn away from love.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Are you going to provide me with an opportunity to prove my love to my girl? Or are you gonna save yourself some trouble and step up like a gentleman and apologize to her?

turns.speaker: IDIOT PUNK
turns.text: Don't fuck with me, man. You look like a clown in that stupid jacket.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: This is a snakeskin jacket, and for me it's a symbol of my individuality and my belief in personal freedom.

turns.speaker: IDIOT PUNK
turns.text: ...Asshole.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Come here.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: I'm sorry to do this to ya here in front of a crowd, but I want ya to stand up and make a nice apology to my girl.

turns.speaker: IDIOT PUNK
turns.text: I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: You are from New Orleans, Senor Farragut?

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: Johnnie, please. Nope. Charlotte, North Carolina. Here on business.

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: Only that it's supposed to be a pretty poor sight since the hurricane came through last year.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Yes, that's so. But there is not much to destroy.

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: In what capacity?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: In many capacities.

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: General Osvaldo Tamarindo y Ramirez. Telefono 666.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: He is my sponsor. The General is the head of the secret police of Honduras.

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: Why are you in New Orleans? If you don't mind my askin'.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Certainly not. We are here only briefly, in fact, until this evening, when we fly to Austin, Texas to visit a friend of mine who is an agent for the CIA.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: The same to you. If you are in Honduras, come to the Bay Islands and visit us. The Hondurans are great friends of the American people. But I have a joke for you before I go. If a liberal, a socialist, and a communist all jumped off the roof of the Empire State Building at the same time, which one of them would hit the ground first?

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: I couldn't say, which one?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Would you like to enjoy a martini with us?

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: Why not? How was the fishin'?

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I think they are too serious, these American fishermen. In Honduras, we are not so concerned with the method.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Teddy Roosevelt, one of the local shrimp boat captains is in jail now. These people are friends of mine, so I must return and find out what happened.

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: This island of yours sounds like a kind of unpredictable place.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: It has its moments of uncertainty.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Hasta siempre.

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: Hasta siempre.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: Do you know how it came about that copper wire was invented in Scotland?

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: How's that?

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: Gotta admit, you guys are -  two in four dozen.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: The real joke is we never went fishing, but we're still fishing.

turns.speaker: REGGIE
turns.text: I forgot to show you this. The gentlemen that gave this to me said you'd recognize it. Said he wanted it'd be 'bout the last thing you ever saw in this life.

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: Oh God... OH GOD... Santos... Oh God Marietta... are you in on this?... OH GOD!!!

turns.speaker: MARIETTA
turns.text: I knew this would happen. Soon as that piece of filth got out of Pee Dee, I knew there'd be trouble. He's just got some kind of influence over her I can't decipher. There's somethin' wild in Lula I don't know where it comes from. You gotta find 'em, Johnnie.

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: He served his time for what he did. Another thing... If Lula went with him of her own volition - willingly, that is - there ain't much can be done about it.

turns.speaker: MARIETTA
turns.text: Don't talk down to me, Johnnie Farragut. I know what volition means, and that's why I want Sailor Ripley off the planet! He's pure slime and it's leakin' all over my baby. Maybe you could push him into makin' some kinda move and then kill him dead. You'd only be defendin' yourself, and with his record, nobody'd fuss.

turns.speaker: MARIETTA
turns.text: I'll hire a hit man if you don't want to help me stop this thing. I'll call Marcello Santos.

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: Now, Marietta, I am goin' to help you. And don't be gettin' carried away. You don't want to be bringin' Santos and his people into it.

turns.speaker: MARIETTA
turns.text: You're just jealous of Santos cause he's sweet on me.

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: Darlin', you ain't seein' Santos again, are ya?

turns.speaker: MARIETTA
turns.text: Oh, Johnnie Farragut... Don't you trust your very own Marietta?

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: Sorry, sweetheart. Bein' in love with you like I am brings out that ugly jealous side.

turns.speaker: MARIETTA
turns.text: Well stop worryin' about me and start worryin' about how you're gonna get that Lula back here and away from that murderer.

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: Sailor ain't a murderer. You got to get off that kick. And far's I can tell, Sailor was entire clean prior to that involvin' Lula. Even there he was protectin' her. You oughta be thankin' him for that. That Bob Ray Lemon they say was comin' after the both of 'em. Why am I tellin' you this, you was around that night. You ought to know just exactly what happened. Sailor just got a little too forceful is all... You remember that night...

turns.speaker: MARIETTA
turns.text: Maybe I was there, but I didn't see anythin'. All I know's that trash killed a man with his bare hands. Hands which are now prob'ly all over my baby!

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: Marietta, settle down now darlin'... I want what's best for her, too - like I said, I'll do what I can to bring her home.

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: No, Marietta, I haven't found 'em.

turns.speaker: MARIETTA
turns.text: This is the kinda mistake can take a Hindu's lifetime to unfix... You better get a move on, Johnnie, before that boy got her holdin' down a Memphis streetcorner and shootin' dope up her arms.

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: Really, Marietta, you got more scenarios swimmin' around in your brain than Carter got pills. Try to take it easy. Go over to Myrtle Beach for a few days.

turns.speaker: MARIETTA
turns.text: I'm stayin' right here by the phone until you find Lula, then I'm comin' to get her. You call soon's you got somethin', even if it's three in the a.m.

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: I will, Marietta. Goodbye now.

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: I got some news, Marietta. Lula and Sailor been here. They checked out of the Hotel Brazil on Frechman Street yesterday.

turns.speaker: MARIETTA
turns.text: Listen, Johnnie, Lula just called me. She knew you were in N.O., so they left the city.

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: Did she tell you where she was callin' from?

turns.speaker: MARIETTA
turns.text: No, but my guess is they're headed west, so prob'ly Texas. Their money must be runnin' low. I don't think Sailor had much to begin with, if any, and Lula took the six hundred she had saved in the Cherokee Thrift.

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: How'd she sound? Was she doin' okay?

turns.speaker: MARIETTA
turns.text: Could she be doin' okay, Johnnie? She's tryin' to prove somethin' to me, that's all. Lula ain't doin' no more'n showin' off, defyin' me...  Johnnie, I've done somethin' bad...

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MARIETTA
turns.text: I won't tell you over the phone. I'm comin' to N.O. and I'll tell you then.

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: Marietta, I was just gonna leave and see if I could pick up their trail.

turns.speaker: MARIETTA
turns.text: No, you wait right there for me... I'll be on the Piedmont flight tomorrow at seven. Meet me at the airport.

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: I'll meet you, Marietta, if that's what you want, but I'm against it.

turns.speaker: MARIETTA
turns.text: Seven tomorrow evenin'. We can eat at Galatoire's. Fix it.

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: Who was that?... Who know's your here?

turns.speaker: MARIETTA
turns.text: I'll be damned if that wasn't a wrong number?

turns.speaker: MARIETTA
turns.text: What is it, Johnnie?

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: Just some guys I met here... I keep seein' 'em...  Now tell me...

turns.speaker: MARIETTA
turns.text: Johnnie, I can't tell you, honey. Is there anyway we can get on the road tonight? We've got to find them kids.

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: Somethin' was upsettin' you bad last night, and you wanted to tell me and I figured you wanted to tell me so's I could help...

turns.speaker: MARIETTA
turns.text: I did, honey, but that was last night... Let's just find those two kids before it's too late.

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: Honey, I have to ask you this... Is Santos involved in any of this?

turns.speaker: MARIETTA
turns.text: Hell no, baby... I wouldn'ta done that without tellin' you.

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: That bastard Pucinski...

turns.speaker: MARIETTA
turns.text: Who?... Uncle Pooch?...

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: Yeah... The one that introduced Santos to you and Clyde.

turns.speaker: MARIETTA
turns.text: Johnnie... That's the past... We gotta get on to our future, sugar!

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: All I have to do is grab my suitcase, and I'm ready. You're lucky cause I happen to love night drivin'.

turns.speaker: MARIETTA
turns.text: Let's head for Texas and see if we can pick up the trail.

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: Did I tell ya it's great to see ya again?

turns.speaker: MARIETTA
turns.text: This 'bout the fifth time?

turns.speaker: MARIETTA
turns.text: I'll pack my things and meet you downstairs.

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: And to think what coulda happened in that king-sized bed tonight...

turns.speaker: MARIETTA
turns.text: You won't of missed much.

turns.speaker: JOHNNIE
turns.text: See ya downstairs.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Don't give me no trouble now, Pace, please. This ain't the easiest day in a long time. And what do you mean how are we gonna know what your daddy looks like? You seen his photo.

turns.speaker: PACE
turns.text: How'll he know what we look like? He seen our photo?

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Damn it, child! Now look what you made me do.

turns.speaker: PACE
turns.text: What I made you do, mama?

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Nothin', honey.  Mama's just actin' strange.

turns.speaker: PACE
turns.text: You ain't actin', mama.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Why, Pace Roscoe Ripley, ain't you got one cute mouth tonight?

turns.speaker: PACE
turns.text: I still ain't sure what my daddy looks like.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Like you, sweetheart. You and your daddy got the same mouth, eyes, ears, and nose. Only difference is your color hair is like mine.

turns.speaker: PACE
turns.text: My daddy ain't never killed nobody, has he, mama?

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Course he ain't never killed nobody. Why'd you say that, Pace?

turns.speaker: PACE
turns.text: Heard grandpa Santos and grandmama talkin'.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: And?

turns.speaker: PACE
turns.text: Grandmama said how Sailor murdered a man.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Wrong, baby. Your daddy never committed no murder. Musta been you didn't hear grandmama proper. He made some mistakes, is all. Your daddy ain't always been so lucky... We're almost at the depot, honey. Sit back a minute.

turns.speaker: PACE
turns.text: Why we sittin' here, mama?

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Thinkin' a second, baby.

turns.speaker: PACE
turns.text: I'm scared, mama.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Why, honey?

turns.speaker: PACE
turns.text: Case daddy don't like me. What if he don't like that I don't got his color hair.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Pace, your daddy'd love you even if you didn't have no hair at all.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Hey baby...

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Peanut...

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Hey, my snakeskin jacket... Thanks, baby... Did I ever tell you that this here jacket for me is a symbol of my individuality and my belief in personal freedom?

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: 'Bout fifty thousand times. I got us a room at the Cape Fear, and guess what?... I hear Powermad's at "The Hurricane."

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Stab it and steer.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Did you ever think somethin' like about the wicked witch of the east comin' flyin' in?... Did you ever think somethin' and then later think you've said it out loud to someone?

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: I really did miss your mind while I was out at Pee Dee, honey. The rest of you, too, of course. But the way your head works is God's own private mystery. What was it you was thinkin'?

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Well, I was thinkin' about smokin' actually... My mama smokes Marlboros now, used to be she smoked Kools? I stole 'em from her beginnin' in about sixth grade. When I got old enough to buy my own, I bought those. Now I've just about settled on Mores, as you probably noticed? They're longer.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: I guess I started smokin' when I was about six... My mama was already dead from lung cancer...

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: What brand'd she smoke?

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Camels, same as me... Guess both my mama and my daddy died of smoke or alcohol related illness.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Gee, Sailor. I'm sorry, honey. I never would have guessed it.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: It's okay. I hardly used to see them anyway. I didn't have much parental guiding. The public defender kept sayin' that at my parole hearin'. He was a good ol' boy, stood by me... Even brought me some cartons of cigarettes from time to time.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: I'd stand by you, Sailor... through anything.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Hell, peanut, you stuck with me after I planted Bob Ray Lemon. A man can't ask for more than that.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: You're perfect for me, too.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: You remind me of my daddy, you know? Mama told me he liked skinny women whose breasts were just a bit too big for their bodies. He had a long nose, too, like theirs. Did I ever tell you how he died?

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: In a fire, as I recall.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Started he couldn't remember things? Got real violent? Mama kept tellin' me it was on account of lead poisoning from cleanin' the old paint off our house without usin' a mask... But I don't know. Seems like his brain just fell apart in pieces.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: You have such a pretty, long neck, like a swan.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Grandmama Pace had a long, smooth white neck. It was like on a statue it was so white?

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Sailor, you are somethin' else, honey... When I was fifteen, Mama told me that pretty soon I'd be startin' to think about sex, and I should talk to her before I did anything about it.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: But honey, I thought you told me your Uncle Pooch raped you when you was thirteen.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: That's true. Uncle Pooch wasn't really an uncle. He was a business partner of my daddy's? And my mama never knew nothin' about me and him - that's for damn sure. His real name was somethin' kind of European, like Pucinski. But everyone just called him Pooch. He came around the house sometimes when Daddy was away. I always figured he was sweet on mama, so when he cornered me one afternoon, I was surprised more'n a little.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: How'd it happen, peanut? He just pull out the old toad and let it croak?

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: You're terrible crude sometimes, Sailor, you know?

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: I can't hardly understand you when you talk with one of them Mores in your mouth.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: I said you can be too crude sometimes? I don't think I care for it.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Sorry, sugar. Go on and tell me how old Pooch done the deed.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Well, mama was at the Busy Bee havin' her hair dyed? And I was alone in the house.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Uncle Pooch came in the side door through the porch, you know? Where I was makin' a jelly and banana sandwich? I remember I had my hair in curlers cause I was goin' that night with Vicki and Cherry Ann, the DeSoto sisters. Uncle Pooch must have known nobody but me was home, cause he came right in and put both his hands on my butt and sorta shoved me up against the counter.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Didn't he say somethin'?

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: So how'd he finally nail you? Right there in the kitchen?

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: No, he picked me up.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: He was short but powerful. With hairy arms? Anyway, he carried me into the maid's dayroom which nobody used. We did it there on an old bed.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: 'We' did it? Whattaya mean? Didn't he force you?

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Well, sure. But he was super-gentle, you know? I mean, he raped me and all, but I guess there's all different kinds of rapes. I didn't exactly want him to do it but I suppose once it started, it didn't seem all that terrible. It was over pretty quick, and after Uncle Pooch just stood there and pulled up his trousers and left me there. I stayed in bed till I heard him drive off. Then I just went back into the kitchen and finished makin' my sandwich.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: And you never told nobody about it?

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Just you. Uncle Pooch never acted strange or different after. And he never did anything else to me. I always got a nice present from him at Christmas, like a coat or jewelry?

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: One hundred twenty decibels - head on collision of a '54 Ford Pick-Up and a '64 Chevy Station Wagon. No survivors. Balls of flame and grinding metal.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Uncle Pooch died in a car crash three years later while he was holidayin' in Myrtle Beach. They still got way too much traffic there for my taste... And another thing, baby... That government of ours should be keepin' us separated from outer space...

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Here she goes again...

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Sailor, that ozone layer is disappearin'. Seems to me the government could do somethin' about it. One of these mornings the sun'll come up and burn a hole clean through the planet like an X-Ray.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: You okay, honey?

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: That woman's laugh creeps me out. I heard somethin' like that... somewhere before... Sound'd like the wicked witch...

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Just sounded like an old gal havin' a good time to me... You ready to dance?

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: I'm always ready to dance. But I need me a kiss first, honey. Just one?

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Hell, you just rubbed up against the wrong girl is all.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: That's good... Now go get yourself a beer.  You fellas have alotta the same power Elvis had... Y'all know this one?

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: What you want to watch this trash for? Ain't one of those people have a real thought in their brain.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: That so?  You want to tell me what, if any, real thoughts you had lately?

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: What you have to get personal about so quick? All I mean is you could possibly read a book.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: What's that honey?

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: We didn't have no TV up at Pee Dee, baby, you know?

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: I'm sorry, sweetie. I forget some moments where all you been the last two years.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Twenty-three months, eighteen days is all. Don't need to make more'n it was.  This couple's goin' on a date to Hawaii. The girl chose him over the other two guys.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Don't the reject guys get anythin'?

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Gift certificates to Kentucky Fried Chicken.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: That don't seem fair.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Hell, why should the Datin' Game be different from real life? At least them boys is gonna get somethin' to eat.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Sailor?

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Wouldn't it be fabulous if we somehow stayed in love for the rest of our lives?

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: You think of the weirdest damn things to say sometimes, peanut. Ain't we been doin' a pretty fair job this far?

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Oh, you know exactly what I mean, honey? It'd make the future so simple and nice.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: At Pee Dee, all you think about is the future, you know? Gettin' out? And what you'll do and what you'll think about when you're on the outside again.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: I just think about things as they come up. I never been much of a planner.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: It ain't altogether terrible just to let things go along sometimes. Lula, I done a few things in my life I ain't too proud of, but I'll tell ya from now on I ain't gonna do nothin' for no good reason. All I know for sure is there's more'n a few bad ideas runnin' around loose out there.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Musta been a lesson tellin' ya it was the wrong time... What did you do, your mama find out?

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: She got me an abortion...

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: ...I hope you appreciate my spendin' six hundred dollars, not countin' what it cost us to get here and back... This man's the best damn abortionist in the South.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: You tell the boy who knocked you up?

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: It was my cousin, Dell, done it? His folks used to visit with us summers.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: What happened to him?

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Oh, nothin'. I never let on to mama about Dell bein' the one. I just flat refused to tell her who the daddy was? I didn't tell Dell, neither. He was back home in Chattanooga by then, anyhow, and I didn't see the point. Somethin' terrible happened to him, though. Six months ago.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: What's that, peanut?

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Dell disappeared. Dell was learnin' a hard lesson. What I learned from observin' Dell is I think people who are frightened want to disappear. He'd startin' behavin' weird? Like comin' up to people every fifteen minutes and askin' how they were doin'?

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Actin' funny how?

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Well, like mama told me, Aunt Rootie, Dell's mama? She found cockroaches in Dell's underwear.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: One time, Aunt Rootie caught Dell puttin' one big cockroach on his anus?

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Hell, peanut...

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: One time - real late - like about two thirty a.m.? She found Dell up in the black of night all dressed and makin' sandwiches in the kitchen.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: ...are followin' him around.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Prob'ly the rain boys from Outer Space.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: It ain't so funny now, though. December before Christmas? Dell disappeared again and Aunt Rootie hired a private eye to find him. He was missin' for almost a month before he wandered back in the house on mornin' dressed in some filthy Santa Claus suit.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: The private eye cost Aunt Rootie over a thousand dollars? Then a little while later Dell ran off a third time to some place he said would "give him peace of mind." Nobody's seen him since.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Sound like ol' Dell's more'n just a little confused, peanut... Too bad he couldn't visit that ol' Wizard of Oz and get some good advice.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Too bad we all can't, baby... One thing about Dell?

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: When he was about seventeen, he startin' losin' his hair.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: So?

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: He's twenty-four now? A year older than you? And must be 'bout bald.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: There's worse things that can happen to a man, honey.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Yeah, I suppose. But you know somethin' baby, hair does make a difference.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Let's go dancin', peanut. I'm ready.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: We gotta be careful, honey, my mama's gonna have Johnnie Farragut on us like a duck on a june bug, and he's one clever detective? You know how clever? He once told me that he could find an honest man in Washington. My toenails gotta dry first anyways, Sailor.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: One thing puzzles my mind, sugar... You're twenty years old - aren't you ever curious why your mama has this fixation on keepin' us apart? Puttin' a detective on us. I'll tell ya Lula... Well... It's more'n me killin' Bob Ray Lemon...

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Maybe my mama cares for me just a little too much...

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Yeah, maybe...

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Sailor!

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: You up for that?

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: I'd got to the far end of the world for you, baby... You know I would.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Those toenails dry yet? We got some dancin' to do.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: ...That's an awful long way to go, just to get some pussy.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Yeah, I had my first taste on that trip to Juarez. At that age you still got a lot of energy.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: You still got plenty energy for me, baby.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Sorry, baby... When's the first time you done it with a girl who wasn't hookin'?

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Maybe two, three months after Juarez. I was visitin' my cousin, Junior Train, in Savannah, and we were at some kid's house whose parents were out of town. A girl comes up to me that was real tall, taller than me.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: She looked right at me and run her tongue over her lips and put her hand on my arm - told me her name was Irma.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: What'd you say to her?

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Told her my name. Then she said somethin' like, 'It's so noisy down here. Why don't we go upstairs so we can hear ourselves?' She turned around and led the way. I knew I had an important lesson to learn that day.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: When she got almost to the top step I stuck my hand between her legs from behind.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Oh, baby. What a bad boy you are!

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: That's just what she said. I had a boner with a capital "O." I went to kiss her but she broke off laughin' and ran down the hallway. I found her lyin' on a bed in a room filled with assault weapons and Penthouse magazines. She was a wild chick. She was wearin' bright orange pants with kind of Spanish lookin' lacy black stripes down the sides. You know, them kind that doesn't go all the way down your leg?

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: You mean like pedal pushers?

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: I guess.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: She just rolled over onto her stomach and stuck her ass up in the air. I slid my hand between her legs and she closed her thighs on it.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: You're excitin' me, honey. What'd she do?

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Her face was half-pushed into the pillow, and she looked back over her shoulder at me and said, 'I won't suck you. Don't ask me to suck you.'

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Poor baby. She don't know what she missed. What color hair she have?

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Sorta brown, blonde, I guess. But dig this, sweetie. Then she turns over, peels off them orange pants, and spreads her legs real wide and says to me...

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: I'll drop mama a postcard from somewhere. I mean, I don't want her to worry no more'n necessary.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: What do you mean by necessary? She's prob'ly already called the cops, my parole officer, her p.i. boyfriend Johnnie Farragut.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: I suppose so. She knew I was bound to see you soon as you was sprung, but I don't figure she counted on us takin' off together like this... I guess this means you're breakin' parole, then?

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: You guess? My parole was broke two hundred miles back when we burnt Portagee County.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: What'll it be like in California, Sailor, do you think? I hear it don't rain much there.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: You got about six more big states to go before we find out.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: We got through two states already.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: That don't smell like a More.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: It ain't. It's part of the lessons of life. I picked me up a pack of Vantages before we left the Cape?

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: They sure do stink.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Yeah, I guess, but - and here's the lesson part - they ain't supposed to be so bad for you.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: You ain't gonna begin worryin' about what's bad for you at this hour, are you, sugar? I mean, here you are crossin' state lines with a A-Number One certified murderer.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Manslaughterer, honey, not murderer. Don't exaggerate.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Okay, manslaughterer who's broke his parole and got in mind nothin' but immoral purposes far's you're concerned.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Thank the Lord. Well, you ain't let me down yet, Sailor. That's more'n I can say for the rest of the world?

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Life is a bitch and then you marry one.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: What kinda trash talk is that?

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: What it says on the bumper sticker up front. On that pickup.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: That's disgustin'. Those kinda sentiments shouldn't be allowed out in public. Is this Biloxi yet?

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Almost. I figure we should find us a place to stay and then go eat.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Got anyplace special in mind?

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: We oughta stay somewhere outta the way. Not in no Holidays or Ramadas or Motel Six. If Johnnie Farragut's on our trail he'll check those first.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: How about that one? The Host of the Old South Hotel.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Looks more like the Ghost of the Old South, but we'll try her.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: I H-A-T-E hotel bedspreads. They don't hardly never get washed, and I don't like the idea of lyin' on other people's dirt.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Come look at this.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: What's that, honey?

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: There ain't no water in the swimmin' pool. Just a dead tree fell in, prob'ly from bein' struck by lightnin'.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: It's huge. This musta been a grand old place at one time.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Let's get fed, sweetheart. The light's fadin' fast.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: M-i-ss-i-ss-i-pp-i... You can almost hear that jazz blowin' up from the big N.O.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Lula... I learned somethin' interestin' today on a science show I heard on the radio... How leeches is comin' back into style.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Say what? Honestly, sugar, you can talk more shit sometimes?

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Got you a pack of Mores again, huh?

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Yeah, it's a real problem for me, Sailor, you know? When I went in that drugstore by the restaurant in Biloxi? I saw 'em by the register and the girl throw 'em in. I'm not big on resistin'. So what about a leech?

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Heard on the radio how doctors is usin' leeches again, just in old times. You know, when even barbers used 'em?

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: I got one on me at Lake Lanier. Lifeguard poured salt on it and it dropped off. Felt awful. He was a cute boy, though, so it was almost worth it.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Yeah, well listen to this... Radio said back in the 1920s a I-talian doctor figured out that if, say, a fella got his nose cut off or bit off in, say, a barfight or somethin', they'd sew one of his forearms to his nose for a few weeks... Then put leeches on it.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Sailor? You expect me to believe a man'd be goin' around with a arm sewed to his nose?

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: How they used to do it. Course they got more sophisticated ways now. Radio said the Chinese, I think it is, figured a better idea is by insertin' a balloon in the forehead and lettin' it hang down on the nose.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Sailor Ripley! You stop! You're makin' this shit up and I ain't gonna sit for it!

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Honest, Lula. I prob'ly ain't precisely got all the facts straight, but it's about what they said.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Honey, we're goin' to bed now and it's time to change the subject.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: We're about dry bones, sweetheart. We don't wanna have to push this "bird" into New Orleans.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: We sure don't, honey...  Get me a Mounds?

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: I love it when your eyes get wild, honey. They light up all blue almost and little white parachutes pop out of 'em. Oh, Sailor you're so aware of what goes on with me? I mean, you pay attention. And I swear, you got the sweetest cock. Sometimes it's like it's talkin' to me when you're inside? Like it's got a voice all it's own. You get right on me.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: You really are dangerously cute, honey. I gotta admit it.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: What lesson do get outta that story, Lula?

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: It's just another case, Sailor.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: What's that, peanut?

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: One person thinks he's doin' somethin' good and ever'body else gets upset about it.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Ever imagine what it'd be like to get eaten alive by a wild beast? Sometimes I think it would be the biggest thrill?

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: My God,  it better be, darlin', cause it'd be the last... What time is it?

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Shhhhh... It's four o'clock... That woman's laugh the other day had somethin' to do with this feelin'?... Like bein' ripped apart by a gorilla, maybe... Grabbed sudden and pulled apart real quick by a real powerful one.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Lula, sometimes I gotta admit, you come up with some weird thoughts...

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Anythin' interestin' in the world come out of somebody's weird thoughts, Sailor. You tell me Sailor, who could come up with shit like we're seein' these days?

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: You got me, peanut.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: You certain?

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: I ain't never met anyone come close to you, sugar.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Recall the time we was sittin' one night behind the Confederate soldier? Leanin' against it. And you took your hand and put it on your heart and you said, 'You feel it beatin' in there, Lula?... Get used to it, 'cause it belongs to you now.' D'you recall that?

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: I do.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: I was hopin' you would. I know that night by heart. Sometimes, honey? I think it's the best night of my life.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: I really do think it's the best night of my life.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: We didn't do nothin' special I can remember. Just talked, is all.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Talkin's good. Long as you got the other? I'm a big believer in talkin', case you ain't noticed.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Too bad they don't give an award for talkin'... You'd win first prize. Especially with those tits.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: You think so, baby? Does my talkin' bother you, honey?

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: No, I like gettin' up around four a.m. and talkin' bout wild animals... Though you woke me up this time in the middle of a dream. I kinda wish I didn't remember it. Up at Pee Dee, I couldn't remember any of my dreams.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: What was this one?

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: It wasn't no fun, Lula. The wind was blowin' super-hard and I wasn't dressed warm. Only instead of freezin', I was sweatin' strong.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: The water was rollin' off me. And I was dirty, too, like I hadn't had no bath in a long time, so the sweat was black almost.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Boy, sweetie, this is weird, okay.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: I know. I kept walkin', I headed for your house, only it wasn't your house, really. You let me in only you weren't real pleased to see me. You kept askin', 'Why'd you come to see me now? Why now?' Like it'd been a long time since we'd seen each other.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Oh, baby, what an idea. I'd always be happy to see you, no matter what.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: I know, peanut. But it wasn't all like you were so unhappy I was there, just you were upset. My bein' there was upsettin' to you. You had some kids there, little kids, and I guess you'd got married and your husband was comin' home any minute.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Sometimes dreams just don't mean nothin'... Stuff comes into your mind and you don't have no control over, you know? Anyways, dreams ain't no odder than real life. Sometimes not by half.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Well, I ain't upset about it, darlin'. Just give me an odd feelin' there a minute, is all.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Let's get outta here... I suddenly got a funny feelin' about this place. Feelin' all that voodoo...

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Gotta hex from a voodoo?

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Who do?

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: You do.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Oh my God... It's Johnnie... Duck down!... Get goin'!

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Where?

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Never mind where... Get outta here... I mean it, Sailor.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: I'm goin'.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: You think he saw us?

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Who knows, baby?

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: He was sittin' there havin' a beignet at the Cafe Du Monde. Do you think he saw us?

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Lula, darlin'... Makes no difference anyway... We're outta here.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Sure you wanna do this? Might be a way they could track us.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: He's just a regular guy't needs help, honey. Look at him.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: You don't feel you was a little hard on the guy, honey?

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: I know you're thinkin' that I got more'n some of my mama in me? Well, I couldn't help it. Sailor, I really couldn't. I'm sorry for that guy, but when he pulled that drippin' hunk of awful-smellin' meat out of his pocket? I near barfed. And them poor diseased puppies!

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Just part of life on the road, peanut.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Do me a favor, Sailor? Don't pick up no more hitchers, okay?

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: I wouldn't mind a little night life. How about you?

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Hard to tell what's shakin' in a place like this, honey. You don't want to be walkin' in the wrong door.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Maybe there's a place we could hear some music. I feel like dancin'. We could ask someone.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: You ready for this?

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: We'll find out in a hurry.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: I'll be damned if I'm leavin'. That band is too good?

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Uh huh.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: You notice that woman when we come in? The white woman sittin' by herself?

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Well, she ain't talked to nobody and ain't nobody spoke to her that I could tell. What you make of that?

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: Honey, we bein' strangers here and all, this is the kinda place we don't want to make nothin' of nothin'.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: You think she's pretty?

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: What's wrong, sweetheart? Somethin' botherin' you?

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Mama. I been thinkin' about her. She's prob'ly worried to death by now.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: More'n likely.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: I want to call her and tell her I'm okay. That we're okay.

turns.speaker: SAILOR
turns.text: I ain't so sure it's a great idea, but that's up to you. Just don't tell her where we are.

turns.speaker: LULA
turns.text: Pardon me? Y'all got a phone here I can use?
